single_hop.question: Which department issues the Code of Practice for Demolition of Buildings?
single_hop.answer: ("entity"|BUILDINGS DEPARTMENT|ORGANIZATION|The Buildings Department is the organization responsible for issuing several key regulatory and guidance documents pertaining to construction, demolition, and site supervision. Specifically, the department issues the Code of Practice for Demolition of Buildings. It is also the organization responsible for issuing the Technical Memorandum for Supervision Plans and the Code of Practice for Site Supervision. Furthermore, the department has a broader mandate of issuing practice notes and overseeing the general administration of building regulations.) ("entity"|CODE OF PRACTICE FOR DEMOLITION OF BUILDINGS|DOCUMENT|The **CODE OF PRACTICE FOR DEMOLITION OF BUILDINGS** is a formal document issued by the Buildings Department. It serves as the authoritative standard outlining the required procedures, safety protocols, and precautionary measures that must be adhered to during the demolition of buildings.  The code is comprehensive in its scope, detailing all necessary precautionary measures to ensure public and worker safety, as well as the structural integrity of adjacent properties. This includes specific standards and specifications for the construction and implementation of protective works such as (1) hoardings, (2) covered walkways, (3) catch platforms, and (4) catchfans. By providing these detailed standards and procedures, the document ensures that demolition work is conducted in a controlled, safe, and methodical manner.) ("relationship"|BUILDINGS DEPARTMENT|CODE OF PRACTICE FOR DEMOLITION OF BUILDINGS|The Buildings Department issues the Code of Practice for Demolition of Buildings|9.0)

boolean.question: Is the Registered Structural Engineer registered under the Buildings Ordinance?
boolean.answer: ("relationship"|REGISTERED STRUCTURAL ENGINEER|BUILDINGS ORDINANCE|The Registered Structural Engineer is registered under the Buildings Ordinance|8.0) ("entity"|BUILDINGS ORDINANCE|REGULATION|The BUILDINGS ORDINANCE is a legal framework governing building and demolition activities in Hong Kong. It serves as the primary regulation under which a Registered Structural Engineer is registered and authorized to operate. The ordinance specifically governs demolition works and the certification of such activities. Furthermore, it provides the legal basis for governing the certification of precautionary works, which are measures taken to ensure safety during construction and demolition processes.)

constraint.question: Which document must be prepared by the Registered Structural Engineer for the Contractor's Stream and explicitly be submitted two months before any demolition works commence?
constraint.answer: ("entity"|SUPERVISION PLAN|DOCUMENT|The SUPERVISION PLAN is a document that must be prepared by the Registered Structural Engineer for the Contractor's Stream. As outlined in the plan, the Registered Structural Engineer is required to assume the role of Authorized Signatory's Representative within the Contractor's Stream. This document is a mandatory submission, required two months before any demolition works commence, and its purpose is to detail the overall supervision strategy for the project.) ("entity"|DEMOLITION PLANS AND STABILITY REPORT|DOCUMENT|A document required for submission two months before demolition works, including calculations and Method Statements) ("entity"|ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT PLAN|DOCUMENT|ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT PLAN is a document that is required for submission two months before the commencement of demolition works. It details comprehensive environmental management strategies. Specifically, the plan provides methods for (1] handling demolished building debris, (2] routing, (3] transportation, and (4] record-keeping.) ("entity"|METHOD STATEMENT|DOCUMENT|METHOD STATEMENT  A METHOD STATEMENT is a comprehensive document or plan detailing the methods for demolition works and other construction-related processes. It is prepared and certified by the RSE (Resident Structural Engineer]. The document includes specifications and details for precautionary measures that are essential to safety.  The METHOD STATEMENT is submitted to the SO (Supervising Officer] for approval. The particulars covered in the submission include: (1] The sources of fill. (2] The particulars of the filling material. (3] The types of construction plant to be used. (4] The compaction method and procedure. (5] The compaction layer thickness. (6] The specific compaction plant to be employed. (7] The site control measures to be implemented.  Furthermore, the METHOD STATEMENT outlines the approved construction sequence for activities such as the installation of the lateral support system and for the process of excavation.) ("entity"|METHOD STATEMENTS|DOCUMENT|METHOD STATEMENTS are documents prepared by the Registered Structural Engineer specifically for demolition works. They constitute detailed plans that are submitted for approval before the commencement of any works. These comprehensive submissions include detailed drawings to outline the proposed methodology and ensure safety and regulatory compliance.) ("entity"|PROJECT SAFETY PLAN|DOCUMENT|A document required for submission two months before demolition works, including the associated Risk Assessment Report) ("entity"|REGISTERED STRUCTURAL ENGINEER|ROLE|REGISTERED STRUCTURAL ENGINEER (RSE] is a qualified professional with a wide range of critical responsibilities in construction and demolition projects. The RSE is fundamentally responsible for method statements, drawings, and design calculations. This includes preparing detailed calculations for structural elements such as sheet piles and lateral support systems, for which the RSE is the designated professional responsible for the design.  The RSE's duties are extensive and can be categorized as follows:  (1] **Design and Certification:** The RSE is responsible for preparing and certifying the Method Statement for construction activities. They are also the professional responsible for certifying demolition plans and reports, as well as endorsing the final certification that completed demolition works have been carried out correctly.  (2] **Geotechnical Coordination:** A specific and critical duty of the RSE is to arrange for a Registered Geotechnical Engineer to handle geotechnical submissions. The RSE ensures that these geotechnical submissions, along with all site supervisions, comply with the statutory requirements set by the Geotechnical Engineering Office (GEO].  (3] **Site Supervision and Endorsement:** The RSE carries out inspections on activities they deem to be critical and requiring close supervision. They act as the Authorized Signatory's Representative within the Contractor's Stream under the Supervision Plan. In this supervisory capacity, the RSE endorses the daily site supervision reports prepared by the TCPs (Technically Competent Persons] and also endorses the certification for any required precautionary works.  In summary, the REGISTERED STRUCTURAL ENGINEER is a pivotal figure ensuring structural integrity, safety, and regulatory compliance through design, certification, coordination with geotechnical specialists, and active site supervision.) ("entity"|RISK ASSESSMENT REPORT|DOCUMENT|A report prepared by Registered Structural Engineer with the Safety Officer including an inspection schedule for staff involved in critical activities in demolition works)

constraint.question: If demolition works cause formation and/or alteration to slopes, retaining walls or other geotechnical features that require geotechnical submissions under current statutory requirements, which professional must the Registered Structural Engineer arrange to prepare those submissions, and where are those submissions submitted?
constraint.answer: ("relationship"|REGISTERED STRUCTURAL ENGINEER|REGISTERED GEOTECHNICAL ENGINEER|Should there be any formation and/or alteration to any slopes, retaining walls and other geotechnical features as a result of the demolition works in the vicinity of the works sites which require geotechnical submissions under current statutory requirements, the RSE arranges for a Registered Geotechnical Engineer to prepare geotechnical submissions. The REGISTERED GEOTECHNICAL ENGINEER is under direct supervision of the RSE|9.0) ("relationship"|REGISTERED GEOTECHNICAL ENGINEER|GEOTECHNICAL ENGINEERING OFFICE|The REGISTERED GEOTECHNICAL ENGINEER submits geotechnical documents to the GEO for approval|8.0) ("relationship"|DEVB TECHNICAL CIRCULAR|GEOTECHNICAL ENGINEERING OFFICE|The DEVB Technical Circular stipulates requirements for submissions to the GEO|6.0) ("entity"|REGISTERED GEOTECHNICAL ENGINEER|ROLE|The REGISTERED GEOTECHNICAL ENGINEER is a professional who operates under the direct supervision of the Registered Structural Engineer (RSE]. The role encompasses two primary areas of responsibility: (1] the preparation of geotechnical submissions and (2] the updating of registrations and manuals. This engineer is tasked with preparing all necessary geotechnical submissions. Furthermore, they are responsible for updating slope registrations and Maintenance Manuals for all affected slopes, retaining walls, and other geotechnical features. These updates are performed through the Geotechnical Engineering Office (GEO] where such action is deemed necessary.) ("entity"|REGISTERED STRUCTURAL ENGINEER|ROLE|REGISTERED STRUCTURAL ENGINEER (RSE] is a qualified professional with a wide range of critical responsibilities in construction and demolition projects. The RSE is fundamentally responsible for method statements, drawings, and design calculations. This includes preparing detailed calculations for structural elements such as sheet piles and lateral support systems, for which the RSE is the designated professional responsible for the design.  The RSE's duties are extensive and can be categorized as follows:  (1] **Design and Certification:** The RSE is responsible for preparing and certifying the Method Statement for construction activities. They are also the professional responsible for certifying demolition plans and reports, as well as endorsing the final certification that completed demolition works have been carried out correctly.  (2] **Geotechnical Coordination:** A specific and critical duty of the RSE is to arrange for a Registered Geotechnical Engineer to handle geotechnical submissions. The RSE ensures that these geotechnical submissions, along with all site supervisions, comply with the statutory requirements set by the Geotechnical Engineering Office (GEO].  (3] **Site Supervision and Endorsement:** The RSE carries out inspections on activities they deem to be critical and requiring close supervision. They act as the Authorized Signatory's Representative within the Contractor's Stream under the Supervision Plan. In this supervisory capacity, the RSE endorses the daily site supervision reports prepared by the TCPs (Technically Competent Persons] and also endorses the certification for any required precautionary works.  In summary, the REGISTERED STRUCTURAL ENGINEER is a pivotal figure ensuring structural integrity, safety, and regulatory compliance through design, certification, coordination with geotechnical specialists, and active site supervision.)

comparison.question: Which provides full-time, on-site supervision of demolition works versus which holds the overall responsibility for overseeing demolition works: SITE ENGINEER or REGISTERED PROFESSIONAL ENGINEER?
comparison.answer: ("entity"|SITE ENGINEER|ROLE|SITE ENGINEER  A Site Engineer is a Registered Professional Engineer who is responsible for the inspection and supervision of demolition works. This role requires the individual to be a Registered Professional Engineer with a minimum of 5 years of relevant experience. The Site Engineer is tasked with providing full-time, on-site supervision to oversee all aspects of the demolition project, ensuring it is carried out safely and in accordance with all relevant regulations and standards.) ("entity"|REGISTERED PROFESSIONAL ENGINEER|ROLE|REGISTERED PROFESSIONAL ENGINEER  A REGISTERED PROFESSIONAL ENGINEER is a qualified engineer who is officially registered in the structural, civil, or building discipline. This individual holds a specific and critical responsibility for overseeing demolition works. To be eligible for this role, the engineer must be a registered professional with a minimum of at least 5 years of relevant practical experience in their field.) ("relationship"|SITE ENGINEER|DEMOLITION WORKS|The site engineer oversees the entire process of demolition works|9.0) ("entity"|DEMOLITION WORKS|PROCESS|The process of demolition works overseen by the site engineer) ("entity"|ON-SITE SUPERVISION|TASK|ON-SITE SUPERVISION is a critical safety process that ensures all demolition works are carried out safely. This function is dedicated to maintaining a secure work environment by providing continuous, direct oversight of demolition activities.) ("entity"|REGISTERED STRUCTURAL ENGINEER|ROLE|REGISTERED STRUCTURAL ENGINEER (RSE] is a qualified professional with a wide range of critical responsibilities in construction and demolition projects. The RSE is fundamentally responsible for method statements, drawings, and design calculations. This includes preparing detailed calculations for structural elements such as sheet piles and lateral support systems, for which the RSE is the designated professional responsible for the design.  The RSE's duties are extensive and can be categorized as follows:  (1] **Design and Certification:** The RSE is responsible for preparing and certifying the Method Statement for construction activities. They are also the professional responsible for certifying demolition plans and reports, as well as endorsing the final certification that completed demolition works have been carried out correctly.  (2] **Geotechnical Coordination:** A specific and critical duty of the RSE is to arrange for a Registered Geotechnical Engineer to handle geotechnical submissions. The RSE ensures that these geotechnical submissions, along with all site supervisions, comply with the statutory requirements set by the Geotechnical Engineering Office (GEO].  (3] **Site Supervision and Endorsement:** The RSE carries out inspections on activities they deem to be critical and requiring close supervision. They act as the Authorized Signatory's Representative within the Contractor's Stream under the Supervision Plan. In this supervisory capacity, the RSE endorses the daily site supervision reports prepared by the TCPs (Technically Competent Persons] and also endorses the certification for any required precautionary works.  In summary, the REGISTERED STRUCTURAL ENGINEER is a pivotal figure ensuring structural integrity, safety, and regulatory compliance through design, certification, coordination with geotechnical specialists, and active site supervision.) ("entity"|SITE AGENT|ROLE|An individual involved in the inspection and supervision of demolition works) ("entity"|SITE|LOCATION|The SITE is the designated location for a construction or demolition project, encompassing a range of key activities and responsibilities. It is the area where demolition, site clearance, and alterations to existing structures are carried out. During these operations, waste materials are generated and are temporarily stored on the SITE before their final disposal.  Furthermore, the SITE is also the location where specific groundworks, namely filling and compaction works, are executed. A critical function of the SITE is as the place where the assumptions made in the design of all temporary works and method statements must be physically validated by a Registered Structural Engineer to ensure safety and integrity.  Following the completion of all demolition and construction activities, the final requirement for the SITE is that it is to be fully reinstated.) ("entity"|TECHNICALLY COMPETENT PERSONS|ROLE|TECHNICALLY COMPETENT PERSONS (TCPs] are individuals defined by their specific qualifications and experience, which are required to supervise demolition works. Their primary role is the on-site supervision of demolition activities. As part of this responsibility, the TCP supervises the demolition workers directly to ensure that all work is carried out in compliance with established safety regulations. Furthermore, the TCP(s] are tasked with the preparation of daily site supervision reports. These reports must subsequently be endorsed by the RSE (Registered Structural Engineer].) ("relationship"|SITE ENGINEER|DEMOLITION PROCESS|A site engineer oversees the demolition process|9.0) ("relationship"|SUPERVISING OFFICER|DEMOLITION PROCESS|The SO oversees the entire demolition process|9.0) ("relationship"|SITE ENGINEER|REGISTERED PROFESSIONAL ENGINEER|The site engineer must be a Registered Professional Engineer in the structural, civil, or building discipline|9.0) ("relationship"|SITE SUPERVISION REPORTS|SITE ENGINEER|The site engineer prepares site supervision reports at various stages of demolition works|8.0) ("relationship"|SITE ENGINEER|SUPERVISING OFFICER|The site engineer submits particulars to the SO for approval and submits site supervision reports after completion of each stage of demolition works and before the commencement of the next stage of demolition works|7.0)

aggregation.question: How many distinct components or topics are included in the Method Statement (i.e., items that the Method Statement includes or that are part of its sketches or submission particulars)?
aggregation.answer: ("entity"|METHOD STATEMENT|DOCUMENT|METHOD STATEMENT  A METHOD STATEMENT is a comprehensive document or plan detailing the methods for demolition works and other construction-related processes. It is prepared and certified by the RSE (Resident Structural Engineer). The document includes specifications and details for precautionary measures that are essential to safety.  The METHOD STATEMENT is submitted to the SO (Supervising Officer) for approval. The particulars covered in the submission include: (1) The sources of fill. (2) The particulars of the filling material. (3) The types of construction plant to be used. (4) The compaction method and procedure. (5) The compaction layer thickness. (6) The specific compaction plant to be employed. (7) The site control measures to be implemented.  Furthermore, the METHOD STATEMENT outlines the approved construction sequence for activities such as the installation of the lateral support system and for the process of excavation.) aggregation.question: How many specific types of materials are explicitly listed under the UNSUITABLE MATERIAL definition?
aggregation.answer: ("entity"|UNSUITABLE MATERIAL|MATERIAL|UNSUITABLE MATERIAL is defined as any material that is not appropriate for use in construction and must be removed from a site. It is fundamentally not fit for its intended purpose. This classification specifically includes material that is not "suitable material" and encompasses substances that are inherently problematic. These substances are characterized by their susceptibility to volume change, which can compromise the structural integrity of a project, and include: (1) peat, (2) vegetation, (3) timber, (4) other organic matter, and (5) soluble substances. The definitive course of action for any material designated as UNSUITABLE MATERIAL is its complete removal from the construction site.) ("relationship"|CONTRACTOR|UNSUITABLE MATERIAL|The contractor removes unsuitable material from the site|8.0)

Their operation is automated with both automatic focus and automatic aperture features.  The installation of these VIDEO CAMERAS is to be directed by the SO (Supervising Officer), who will identify strategic locations to ensure comprehensive coverage. They are specified to have a specific resolution, a wide view angle coverage, and a particular light sensitivity. Their operation is automated with both automatic focus and automatic aperture features.  The installation of these VIDEO CAMERAS is to be directed by the SO (Supervising Officer), who will identify strategic locations to ensure comprehensive coverage. The cameras must be securely protected from potential damage during the demolition activities. Their primary function is to capture the full scope of the demolition, including the movement of debris and the overall sequence of events from start to finish.  A critical requirement for these VIDEO CAMERAS is the retention of the video records they produce. These records must be kept available for inspection for a minimum period of 14 days after the recording is made.) ("entity"|VIDEO RECORDS|DOCUMENT|The video records shall be kept for inspection for at least 14 days, capturing the entire demolition process including debris movement and sequence of demolition) ("relationship"|VIDEO RECORDS|SUPERVISING OFFICER|The SO inspects the video records kept for at least 14 days|8.0)

constraint.question: Which regulatory body must give prior approval for the ABATEMENT PLAN before asbestos removal works proceed?
constraint.answer: ("entity"|ABATEMENT PLAN|DOCUMENT|A plan requiring prior approval by the Environmental Protection Department and the SO for asbestos removal works) ("entity"|ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION DEPARTMENT|ORGANIZATION|The **ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION DEPARTMENT** is a regulatory body responsible for environmental protection and pollution control. Its comprehensive mandate includes the management of hazardous materials, waste, and construction-related environmental impacts.  Specifically, the department is the primary authority for asbestos control. It is the body to which all asbestos reports and abatement plans must be submitted for approval. It also approves specific asbestos removal methods, such as the glove bag technique. Furthermore, the department is responsible for publishing the relevant Code of Practice, receiving notifications for asbestos waste disposal, and ensuring overall compliance with asbestos control regulations.  Beyond asbestos, the department's responsibilities include: (1) Maintaining a listing of licensed contractors who are authorized to handle hazardous waste. (2) Approving noise permits required for demolition works. (3) Approving broader environmental measures for projects, including those related to site drainage and effluent discharge.) ("relationship"|ABATEMENT PLAN|ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION DEPARTMENT|The abatement plan requires prior approval by the Environmental Protection Department|8.0)

constraint.question: According to the defined excavation process, what approvals or inspections are required before any new work (such as laying foundations or pipes) can commence within the excavation?
constraint.answer: ("entity"|EXCAVATION|PROCESS|EXCAVATION is the process of digging, removing, and displacing earth or other materials from a site. It is a foundational activity undertaken to prepare a location for subsequent construction or other works, such as creating structures, pits, or trenches. The process is not a single action but a carefully planned operation that proceeds in distinct stages. These stages must be executed in accordance with an approved construction sequence, which can be found either within a formal method statement or a separately designed sequence, depending on which is applicable for the project.  Due to the inherent risks involved, EXCAVATION is a heavily regulated activity with specific requirements. Key among these are mandates for ensuring the stability of the excavated area and for providing adequate drainage to prevent water accumulation. Furthermore, the process requires thorough planning, including the submission of a proposed sequence of works and the implementation of a monitoring system to oversee the activities and ensure safety.  Before any new work, such as laying foundations or pipes, can commence within the excavation, the site must receive official approval and undergo a mandatory inspection. EXCAVATION also serves as a critical step in addressing site obstructions; it is a key component in several approved methods for overcoming obstructions, as it involves digging and removing material to physically access the impediment.) ("relationship"|BOTTOMS OF EXCAVATION|EXCAVATION|The bottom of the excavation must be inspected and approved before new work begins|7.0) ("relationship"|EXCAVATION|SO|The SO must approve and inspect excavation work before it proceeds|8.0)

aggregation.question: How many distinct procedural requirements (processes or conditions) are required before or during ASBESTOS REMOVAL WORKS?
aggregation.answer: ("entity"|FULL CONTAINMENT METHOD|PROCESS|The FULL CONTAINMENT METHOD is a procedure applied to the removal of friable asbestos materials. Its primary purpose is to ensure containment and minimize the release of asbestos fibers into the surrounding environment during abatement works.) ("entity"|SMOKE TEST|PROCESS|A test conducted by a registered asbestos consultant to ensure the integrity of the full containment before asbestos removal works commence) ("entity"|NEGATIVE PRESSURE|MEASUREMENT|NEGATIVE PRESSURE is a critical condition and a mandatory requirement that must be established and maintained during asbestos removal works. Its sole and essential purpose is to prevent the release of asbestos fibers from the enclosed work area into surrounding environments. By ensuring the air pressure inside the containment is lower than the pressure outside it, any potential airflow is directed inward, thereby trapping hazardous fibers within the designated work zone and protecting the health and safety of occupants and workers outside of it.) aggregation.question: How many distinct types of filling material are identified?
aggregation.answer: ("entity"|ROCK FILLING MATERIAL|MATERIAL|ROCK FILLING MATERIAL is a specified construction material used for filling and compaction. It consists of pieces of concrete or hard and durable rock. A key specification is that the maximum size of any individual piece must not be greater than three times its minimum dimension. Furthermore, in the opinion of the SO (Supervising Officer), no more than 30% of the material's mass can be discoloured or show other evidence of decomposition.  The material is graded by size, and specific mass requirements are mandated for sampling: (1) Each sample of rock filling material with a Grade size not exceeding 200 shall have a mass of at least 250 kg. (2) Each sample of rock filling material with a Grade size exceeding 200 shall have a mass of at least 1000 kg.  The compaction process for ROCK FILLING MATERIAL involves several strict procedures. Each layer placed for compaction must not exceed a thickness of 400mm. Before depositing the next layer, the surface voids of the current layer must be filled with fragments of rock. The final surface of the compacted material requires blinding with fine filling material. For final compaction, the surface must be compacted by a minimum of two additional passes of a vibratory roller; alternatively, other equivalent plant approved by the SO may be used.) ("entity"|GENERAL FILLING MATERIAL|MATERIAL|GENERAL FILLING MATERIAL is a type of suitable construction material primarily used for filling and compaction purposes. It is characterized by having a large portion of coarse material, making it appropriate for compaction by method specification. The material has specific composition and size requirements: it may contain up to 25% rock, which must be distributed evenly throughout the mass. Furthermore, no individual piece of material within it is permitted to exceed 200mm in its largest dimension.  Its gradation is defined by the requirement that less than 90% of the material passes a 20mm British Standard (BS) test sieve. This standard is applied to sections as explicitly shown on construction drawings. Once placed, the material must be compacted to achieve a relative compaction (RC) of at least 90% to ensure structural stability and meet engineering specifications.) ("entity"|RECYCLED ROCK FILLING MATERIAL (GRADE 200)|MATERIAL|Recycled rock filling material (Grade 200) is recycled rock or inert construction and demolition material which is hard and durable, and free from cracks, veins, and other evidence of decomposition)

aggregation.question: How many distinct processes and equipment are directly associated with the compaction process?
aggregation.answer: ("entity"|COMPACTION|PROCESS|COMPACTION is the process of compressing backfill material to ensure the stability and required density of the filled area. This process necessitates the use of specific equipment and adherence to defined procedures. It is performed systematically on each layer of rock filling material. The procedure for each layer involves first spreading and leveling the material. This is followed by the systematic compaction of the layer, which is achieved by a minimum of 8 passes of a vibratory roller.) ("entity"|COMPACTION PLANT|EQUIPMENT|COMPACTION PLANT is the specific equipment used to ensure the proper compaction and to achieve the required density of filling material. It is the machinery designated for all compaction procedures involving such materials.) ("entity"|FIELD DENSITY TESTS|PROCESS|Field density tests are conducted to determine the in-situ density of the material) ("entity"|EARTH MOVING PLANT|EQUIPMENT|Earth moving plant is equipment not accepted for compaction under the specified clause) ("entity"|VIBRATORY ROLLER|EQUIPMENT|The VIBRATORY ROLLER is an approved piece of equipment used for compacting layers of filling material. Its application is specified for two distinct tasks, each with a specific minimum static load requirement per 100mm width of the roller:  (1) For general compaction work, the VIBRATORY ROLLER must have a minimum static load of 2kN per 100mm width of roller. Alternatively, other equivalent plant may be used if it has received approval from the SO (Supervising Officer).  (2) For rolling the trimmed formation, the VIBRATORY ROLLER must have a minimum static load of 0.7kN per 100mm width of vibratory roller.)

aggregation.question: How many distinct considerations or constraints are explicitly required to be accounted for in the design or use of TEMPORARY WORKS?
aggregation.answer: ("entity"|TEMPORARY WORKS|INFRASTRUCTURE|TEMPORARY WORKS are structures that are erected on a construction site prior to the commencement of the actual, permanent works. A primary example of their application is in demolition, where they are built before the actual demolition process begins. These works encompass a wide range of engineered structures necessary for construction activities. This includes, but is not limited to, slopes, stockpiles, and drainage systems that are specifically designed for earthworks projects.  A fundamental principle governing the design and implementation of TEMPORARY WORKS is that the risk of their failure must not be greater than the risk that would be deemed acceptable if the structure in question were a permanent one. This ensures that even though these structures are not intended to remain for the long term, they are engineered to a high standard of safety and reliability throughout their operational lifespan.) ("entity"|DESIGN LIFE|MEASUREMENT|The design life refers to the expected duration for which temporary works are designed, accounting for their shorter lifespan compared to permanent works) ("entity"|RISK TO PERSONS AND PROPERTY|REQUIREMENT|The risk to persons and property must be considered in the design of temporary works to ensure safety during construction) ("entity"|SURFACE WATER AND GROUNDWATER CONDITIONS|MEASUREMENT|Surface water and groundwater conditions are environmental factors that must be accounted for in temporary works design) ("entity"|STEEL SHEET PILES|MATERIAL|Steel sheet piles that can be re-used from other sites if their physical conditions are satisfactory and used as temporary works)

This ensures that even though these structures are not intended to remain for the long term, they are engineered to a high standard of safety and reliability throughout their operational lifespan.) constraint.question: Which defined material explicitly meets the chemical constraint for placement within 500 mm of concrete?
constraint.answer: ("entity"|SUITABLE MATERIAL|MATERIAL|SUITABLE MATERIAL is defined as a naturally occurring or processed material, or inert construction and demolition material, that is capable of being compacted to form stable areas of fill. It is deemed appropriate for use in backfilling and other construction processes and is specifically specified for use in watercourse diversion and filling operations.  The material's composition is subject to strict chemical limits to prevent damage to adjacent construction materials: (1) For material placed within 500mm of concrete, cement-bound material, or cementitious material, the soluble sulphate content must not exceed 1.9g of sulphate (expressed as SO) per litre. (2) For material placed within 500mm of metalwork, the total sulphate content (expressed as SO) must not exceed 0.5% by mass.)

constraint.answer: ("entity"|EXPOSED MATERIAL|MATERIAL|Material exposed after excavation that must be assessed for backfilling suitability) ("entity"|SO|ROLE|SO (Supervising Officer) is a role with comprehensive authority and responsibility for overseeing, directing, and approving a wide range of construction and site activities. The SO is the individual or entity responsible for confirming the disposal of asbestos waste by reviewing the trip ticket. The SO's office is where ground investigation reports are made available for inspection.  The SO's duties and authorities are extensive and include: (1) Overseeing the accuracy of site levels and approving surveys and drawings. (2) Reviewing and approving the Contractor's designs and measures for temporary works. (3) Overseeing, approving, and inspecting excavation work, including the approval of materials and processes used. (4) Regulating, restricting, or prohibiting blasting operations for safety and noise control, including approving locations where the Contractor wishes to use more than 10kg of explosive in a single blast. (5) Approving method statements for various works, including filling, compaction, and the overcoming of obstructions. (6) Approving test results, the placement of fill layers, and compaction requirements. The SO directs when and how tests should be carried out, has the authority to reject consignments, and requires control tests. (7) Approving the size of filling material and equivalent plant for compaction processes. (8) Directing construction activities and work sequencing. (9) Having discretion over the incorporation of boulders in embankments. (10) Directing the recompaction of a surface at no extra cost if the moisture content of the compacted material exceeds the maximum permitted value. (11) Being the recipient of documents such as the sheet pile record and copies of the repair and cleaning guideline for comment and approval. (12) Checking the calibration of sheet piles at 1-meter intervals and directing when to burn off damaged sheet piles. (13) Approving methods to overcome obstructions encountered during work and evaluating the fitness of piles for re-driving. (14) Approving all materials, samples, stone works, sample panels, and membranes. (15) Liaising with regarding access to the Site and the execution of ground investigation works. (16) Carrying out formal approval for each stage of the work.  The SO is the central approving authority for various options and procedures throughout the construction process.) aggregation.question: How many distinct materials are specified for use in embankment construction?
aggregation.answer: ("entity"|EMBANKMENTS|STRUCTURE|EMBANKMENTS are raised structures constructed from compacted earthwork material. They are specifically built on both sides of culverts or drain pipes and are required to meet specified compaction requirements.) ("entity"|SPECIAL FILLING MATERIAL|MATERIAL|SPECIAL FILLING MATERIAL is a designated construction material primarily used for building embankments and as a backfilling material for specific sections as indicated on engineering drawings. Its specifications are rigorously defined by a set of geotechnical properties to ensure its suitability for these applications.  The material is characterized by its particle size and consistency. It must be capable of passing through a 75mm British Standard (BS) sieve. Furthermore, it has strict gradation requirements regarding its fine content, stipulating that less than 45% of the material's mass can pass a 63m BS sieve.  Its engineering behavior is controlled by its consistency limits. The material must have a liquid limit that does not exceed 45% and a plasticity index that does not exceed 20%. Additionally, its particle size distribution is defined by a coefficient of uniformity that must be greater than 50.  In summary, SPECIAL FILLING MATERIAL is a specified, well-graded fill with controlled fines content and plasticity, making it a suitable and engineered choice for constructing stable embankments and for designated backfilling operations.) ("entity"|EARTHWORK MATERIAL|MATERIAL|Material used for filling and compaction in earthworks) ("entity"|FINE FILLING MATERIAL|MATERIAL|Fine Filling Material is a specific type of approved construction material. It is defined by its granular size, being suitable material that is capable of passing through a 75mm British Standard (BS) sieve. Its primary function is to be used for blinding the top surface and the side slopes of embankments.) ("entity"|TOPSOIL|MATERIAL|TOPSOIL is a specific type of material defined for use in construction and landscaping, particularly on the side slopes and verges of embankments. According to Clause 3.1, its application for these areas is formally specified.  The material is characterized as a fine, high-quality soil. Its primary function on embankments is for sealing the side slopes and verges. The processing and handling of topsoil are subject to specific requirements to preserve its quality. It is the soil layer that is carefully removed from a site before any major excavation or filling work begins. This removed topsoil is not discarded; instead, it is stored in a temporary location for later reuse on the same project. During this storage period, it is imperative to keep the stockpile free from any contamination and to prevent it from becoming compacted, ensuring it remains suitable for its intended final application.) ("relationship"|EMBANKMENTS|SPECIAL FILLING MATERIAL|Embankments are to be formed of special filling material|8.0) ("relationship"|EMBANKMENTS|EARTHWORK MATERIAL|Embankments are built using earthwork material|8.0) ("relationship"|FINE FILLING MATERIAL|EMBANKMENT|Fine filling material is used to blind the top surface and side slopes of embankments|6.0) ("relationship"|TOPSOIL|EMBANKMENT|Topsoil is used to seal side slopes and verges of embankments|6.0)

comparison.question: Which material has more stringent geotechnical limits, SPECIAL FILLING MATERIAL or FINE FILLING MATERIAL?
comparison.answer: ("entity"|SPECIAL FILLING MATERIAL|MATERIAL|SPECIAL FILLING MATERIAL is a designated construction material primarily used for building embankments and as a backfilling material for specific sections as indicated on engineering drawings. Its specifications are rigorously defined by a set of geotechnical properties to ensure its suitability for these applications.  The material is characterized by its particle size and consistency. It must be capable of passing through a 75mm British Standard (BS) sieve. Furthermore, it has strict gradation requirements regarding its fine content, stipulating that less than 45% of the material's mass can pass a 63m BS sieve.  Its engineering behavior is controlled by its consistency limits. The material must have a liquid limit that does not exceed 45% and a plasticity index that does not exceed 20%. Additionally, its particle size distribution is defined by a coefficient of uniformity that must be greater than 50.  In summary, SPECIAL FILLING MATERIAL is a specified, well-graded fill with controlled fines content and plasticity, making it a suitable and engineered choice for constructing stable embankments and for designated backfilling operations.) ("entity"|FINE FILLING MATERIAL|MATERIAL|Fine Filling Material is a specific type of approved construction material. It is defined by its granular size, being suitable material that is capable of passing through a 75mm British Standard (BS) sieve. Its primary function is to be used for blinding the top surface and the side slopes of embankments.) ("entity"|FILLING MATERIAL|MATERIAL|FILLING MATERIAL is a fundamental component used in construction projects. It is a general material obtained from excavation on the site itself, from designated borrow areas, or from other sources that have received official approval. Its primary function is to be deposited and compacted to form stable, level surfaces and to fill voids.  The specific applications for FILLING MATERIAL are varied and include being used for filling and compaction, for constructing platforms and slopes, for depositing and compacting within foundation pits and trenches, and for backfilling behind structures like retaining walls where it must be compacted to meet specified engineering requirements.  The placement and compaction of FILLING MATERIAL are governed by strict procedures to ensure structural integrity: (1] The material must be deposited in horizontal layers. The thickness of each layer is not arbitrary but must be appropriate for the specific compaction method being employed. (2] A critical requirement during deposition is to achieve a good bond between successive layers of fill. (3] Unless specific alternative instructions are given by the Supervising Officer (SO], no new material is to be placed on top of a previously compacted layer until that layer's surface has been properly prepared. This preparation involves scarifying or otherwise breaking up the compacted surface to ensure proper interlocking with the new layer and, if necessary, watering it to achieve the optimum moisture content for compaction.)

single_hop.question: From where can filling material be sourced?
single_hop.answer: ("relationship"|FILLING MATERIAL|BORROW AREAS|Filling material can be sourced from borrow areas|7.0) ("entity"|FILLING MATERIAL|MATERIAL|FILLING MATERIAL is a fundamental component used in construction projects. It is a general material obtained from excavation on the site itself, from designated borrow areas, or from other sources that have received official approval. Its primary function is to be deposited and compacted to form stable, level surfaces and to fill voids.  The specific applications for FILLING MATERIAL are varied and include being used for filling and compaction, for constructing platforms and slopes, for depositing and compacting within foundation pits and trenches, and for backfilling behind structures like retaining walls where it must be compacted to meet specified engineering requirements.  The placement and compaction of FILLING MATERIAL are governed by strict procedures to ensure structural integrity: (1] The material must be deposited in horizontal layers. The thickness of each layer is not arbitrary but must be appropriate for the specific compaction method being employed. (2] A critical requirement during deposition is to achieve a good bond between successive layers of fill. (3] Unless specific alternative instructions are given by the Supervising Officer (SO], no new material is to be placed on top of a previously compacted layer until that layer's surface has been properly prepared. This preparation involves scarifying or otherwise breaking up the compacted surface to ensure proper interlocking with the new layer and, if necessary, watering it to achieve the optimum moisture content for compaction.) ("relationship"|SITE|FILLING MATERIAL|Filling material can be obtained from excavation on Site|7.0)

single_hop.question: What is used to calculate the relative compaction?
single_hop.answer: ("relationship"|RELATIVE COMPACTION|IDD|IDD is used to calculate the relative compaction|9.0) ("entity"|RC|MEASUREMENT|Relative Compaction (RC] is a percentage measurement used to specify and quantify the quality of compaction for filling material. It is calculated by taking the In-Place Dry Density (IDD] of the compacted soil, dividing it by the Maximum Dry Density (MDD] obtained from a laboratory compaction test, and then multiplying the result by 100% (i.e., RC = (IDD / MDD]  100%]. This metric provides a direct comparison between the density achieved in the field and the highest possible density achievable for that specific soil under controlled conditions. Unless otherwise stated by a project's specifications, a minimum Relative Compaction of 90% is a standard requirement to ensure the fill material possesses adequate strength and low compressibility for its intended engineering purpose.) ("entity"|RELATIVE COMPACTION|MEASUREMENT|RELATIVE COMPACTION is a measurement of compaction quality and the density of a material compared to its maximum density. It is calculated as the ratio (expressed as a percentage] of the in-situ field density to the maximum dry density. This calculation is performed using the formula: In-Situ Dry Density (IDD] divided by Maximum Dry Density (MDD] multiplied by 100% (IDD/MDD x 100%].) ("relationship"|RELATIVE COMPACTION|MDD|MDD is used to calculate the relative compaction|9.0)

Its manufacture, composition, and application are governed by strict British Standards.  For use in tanking applications, MASTIC ASPHALT must comply with type T1097 as specified in the standard BS 6925. This type is defined by its use of lime stone aggregate. To ensure traceability and compliance, every block of mastic asphalt delivered to a construction site is required to bear legible markings identifying the manufacturer, the relevant British Standard number (BS 6925], the date of that standard, and the type number (T1097].  The material's composition and physical properties are rigorously tested. The testing for composition and hardness number is conducted in accordance with the methods set out in British Standard BS 5284. The process for applying mastic asphalt involves remelting the delivered blocks on the construction site before application.  When MASTIC ASPHALT is being laid horizontally as a surface, specific sampling procedures must be followed to ensure quality control. A sample of the material is taken during the laying process. The requirements for this sample are precise, mandating a minimum sample size of 6 kilograms for subsequent testing.) single_hop.question: What is used to bond random rubble walling through the full thickness of the wall?

This single piece must have a minimum size of 450mm x 150mm and its purpose is to bond the wall through its full thickness.  For squared rubble walling, the requirement is more stringent. At least two pieces of bonding rubble are required per square meter. These pieces must be regularly spaced within that area to effectively bond the squared rubble walling.) ("entity"|RANDOM RUBBLE WALLING|STRUCTURE|RANDOM RUBBLE WALLING is a specific type of masonry construction. It is characterized by its use of rubble stones, which are of irregular, non-uniform, and random shapes and sizes. These stones are bonded together to form the structure of the wall. boolean.question: Does MASTIC ASPHALT have to comply with BS 6925?
boolean.answer: ("entity"|MASTIC ASPHALT|MATERIAL|MASTIC ASPHALT is a construction material, specifically a type of asphalt used for laying surfaces and for the specialized waterproofing process known as tanking. Its manufacture, composition, and application are governed by strict British Standards.  For use in tanking applications, MASTIC ASPHALT must comply with type T1097 as specified in the standard BS 6925. This type is defined by its use of lime stone aggregate. To ensure traceability and compliance, every block of mastic asphalt delivered to a construction site is required to bear legible markings identifying the manufacturer, the relevant British Standard number (BS 6925), the date of that standard, and the type number (T1097).  The material's composition and physical properties are rigorously tested. The testing for composition and hardness number is conducted in accordance with the methods set out in British Standard BS 5284. The process for applying mastic asphalt involves remelting the delivered blocks on the construction site before application.  When MASTIC ASPHALT is being laid horizontally as a surface, specific sampling procedures must be followed to ensure quality control. A sample of the material is taken during the laying process. The requirements for this sample are precise, mandating a minimum sample size of 6 kilograms for subsequent testing.) ("entity"|BS 6925|DOCUMENT|BS 6925 is a British Standard that specifies the requirements for mastic asphalt with limestone aggregate. This standard is specifically applied for use in tanking, which is a form of damp proofing or waterproofing used to prevent moisture from passing through the walls and floors of structures.) ("relationship"|MASTIC ASPHALT|BS 6925|Mastic asphalt must comply with BS 6925|8.0)

It is prepared and certified by the RSE (Resident Structural Engineer]. The document includes specifications and details for precautionary measures that are essential to safety.  The METHOD STATEMENT is submitted to the SO (Supervising Officer] for approval. The particulars covered in the submission include: (1] The sources of fill. (2] The particulars of the filling material. (3] The types of construction plant to be used. (4] The compaction method and procedure. (5] The compaction layer thickness. (6] The specific compaction plant to be employed. (7] The site control measures to be implemented.  Furthermore, the METHOD STATEMENT outlines the approved construction sequence for activities such as the installation of the lateral support system and for the process of excavation.) aggregation.question: Which construction component requires the maximum single specified extension or embedding length (maximum of the specified 100mm, 75mm, 250mm, and 450mm values)?
aggregation.answer: ("entity"|WALL TIES|EQUIPMENT|WALL TIES are components used in masonry construction to connect and stabilize stone walls, such as when a new wall is built to face an existing one. For each tie, one end must be fixed 100mm into the structural wall, while the other end must be fixed 75mm into the masonry of the facing wall. The ties must project 250mm into the masonry.  Regarding their placement, the ties must be fixed between the ends of walls and between concrete and brickwork. They are to be spaced at centers of at least 450mm apart vertically.) ("entity"|BONDING STONES|MATERIAL|BONDING STONES are materials used in the construction of squared rubble stone walls. Their primary function is to bond the wall together, ensuring structural integrity. As stipulated in Clause 10.16 (a), these stones are integrated into the wall by being carried through its full thickness. If the wall's full thickness is not practicable, the bonding stones must extend at least 450mm into the wall's backing or core.)

("entity"|ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION DEPARTMENT|ORGANIZATION|The **ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION DEPARTMENT** is a regulatory body responsible for environmental protection and pollution control. Its comprehensive mandate includes the management of hazardous materials, waste, and construction-related environmental impacts.  Specifically, the department is the primary authority for asbestos control. It is the body to which all asbestos reports and abatement plans must be submitted for approval. It also approves specific asbestos removal methods, such as the glove bag technique. Furthermore, the department is responsible for publishing the relevant Code of Practice, receiving notifications for asbestos waste disposal, and ensuring overall compliance with asbestos control regulations.  Beyond asbestos, the department's responsibilities include: (1] Maintaining a listing of licensed contractors who are authorized to handle hazardous waste. (2] Approving noise permits required for demolition works. (3] Approving broader environmental measures for projects, including those related to site drainage and effluent discharge.) ("entity"|FULL CONTAINMENT METHOD|PROCESS|The FULL CONTAINMENT METHOD is a procedure applied to the removal of friable asbestos materials. Its primary purpose is to ensure containment and minimize the release of asbestos fibers into the surrounding environment during abatement works.) ("entity"|SO|ROLE|SO (Supervising Officer] is a role with comprehensive authority and responsibility for overseeing, directing, and approving a wide range of construction and site activities. The SO is the individual or entity responsible for confirming the disposal of asbestos waste by reviewing the trip ticket. The SO's office is where ground investigation reports are made available for inspection.  The SO's duties and authorities are extensive and include: (1] Overseeing the accuracy of site levels and approving surveys and drawings. (2] Reviewing and approving the Contractor's designs and measures for temporary works. (3] Overseeing, approving, and inspecting excavation work, including the approval of materials and processes used. (4] Regulating, restricting, or prohibiting blasting operations for safety and noise control, including approving locations where the Contractor wishes to use more than 10kg of explosive in a single blast. (5] Approving method statements for various works, including filling, compaction, and the overcoming of obstructions. (6] Approving test results, the placement of fill layers, and compaction requirements. The SO directs when and how tests should be carried out, has the authority to reject consignments, and requires control tests. (7] Approving the size of filling material and equivalent plant for compaction processes. (8] Directing construction activities and work sequencing. (9] Having discretion over the incorporation of boulders in embankments. (10] Directing the recompaction of a surface at no extra cost if the moisture content of the compacted material exceeds the maximum permitted value. (11] Being the recipient of documents such as the sheet pile record and copies of the repair and cleaning guideline for comment and approval. (12] Checking the calibration of sheet piles at 1-meter intervals and directing when to burn off damaged sheet piles. (13] Approving methods to overcome obstructions encountered during work and evaluating the fitness of piles for re-driving. (14] Approving all materials, samples, stone works, sample panels, and membranes. (15] Liaising with regarding access to the Site and the execution of ground investigation works. (16] Carrying out formal approval for each stage of the work.  The SO is the central approving authority for various options and procedures throughout the construction process.) ("relationship"|SUPERVISING OFFICER|ASBESTOS ABATEMENT PLAN|The plan must be approved by the SO|8.0) ("relationship"|ASBESTOS REMOVAL WORKS|FULL CONTAINMENT METHOD|The full containment method is applied to asbestos removal works|9.0)

aggregation.question: How many distinct materials or tools are associated with ROCK CUTTINGS?
aggregation.answer: ("entity"|ROCK CUTTINGS|PROCESS|Excavated rock faces requiring special treatment) ("entity"|SOFT MATERIAL|MATERIAL|SOFT MATERIAL is a term used in geotechnical or excavation contexts to describe specific subsurface conditions. It refers to layers or pockets of unconsolidated, weak, or compressible earth found within a site. The presence of SOFT MATERIAL is a significant concern for construction and engineering projects, as it necessitates removal to ensure structural integrity and stability.  Based on the provided descriptions, SOFT MATERIAL is identified in two distinct locations. (1) It is found in the bottoms of pits and trenches, where it exists in concentrated pockets. (2) It is also found as layers situated between more competent rock strata. In both of these scenarios, the material is deemed unsuitable for supporting structural loads. Consequently, a critical common requirement for both conditions is that this SOFT MATERIAL must be excavated and removed from the site before subsequent construction work can proceed.) constraint.answer: ("entity"|EXCAVATION|PROCESS|EXCAVATION is the process of digging, removing, and displacing earth or other materials from a site. It is a foundational activity undertaken to prepare a location for subsequent construction or other works, such as creating structures, pits, or trenches. The process is not a single action but a carefully planned operation that proceeds in distinct stages. These stages must be executed in accordance with an approved construction sequence, which can be found either within a formal method statement or a separately designed sequence, depending on which is applicable for the project.  Due to the inherent risks involved, EXCAVATION is a heavily regulated activity with specific requirements. Key among these are mandates for ensuring the stability of the excavated area and for providing adequate drainage to prevent water accumulation. Furthermore, the process requires thorough planning, including the submission of a proposed sequence of works and the implementation of a monitoring system to oversee the activities and ensure safety.  Before any new work, such as laying foundations or pipes, can commence within the excavation, the site must receive official approval and undergo a mandatory inspection. EXCAVATION also serves as a critical step in addressing site obstructions; it is a key component in several approved methods for overcoming obstructions, as it involves digging and removing material to physically access the impediment.) ("entity"|BOTTOMS OF EXCAVATION|STRUCTURE|The base of an excavated area that must be inspected and approved before new work begins) ("relationship"|EXCAVATION|BOTTOMS OF EXCAVATION|The bottom of the excavation must be inspected and approved before new work begins|7.0)

aggregation.question: What is the minimum number of days specified across these requirements: the concrete curing period, the notification to the Utility Undertaking before commencement, and the timeframe within which protection must be applied after work completion?

This process allows the concrete to achieve its desired strength and durability. The specific instruction is that concrete must be properly cured for a minimum period of at least 7 days. Only after this curing period is complete can subsequent construction activities ("the Works") be safely carried out on or over the concrete slab.
